newsitem.title: USA: Local groups oppose planned U.S. Bancorp merger.
newsitem.headline: Local groups oppose planned U.S. Bancorp merger.

text.p: First Bank System Inc.'s proposed $8.5 billion acquisition of U.S. Bancorp has run into opposition from groups unhappy with the companies' community banking records, a Federal Reserve spokeswoman said Friday.
Chris Power, a spokeswoman for the Minneapolis Fed, which regulates Minneapolis-based First Bank, said several community groups have filed letters of complaint about the merger.
The letters, received before last week's deadline, will be forwarded to the Fed's Board of Governors in Washington, which must decide whether to approve the merger.
At least one of the groups, the Black United Front in Portland, accused the banks of doing a poor job of serving African-American consumers, according to the Oregonian newspaper.

The group is asking the Fed to delay the merger and hold public hearings on it, contending that U.S. Bank denied home loans to African-Americans at a much higher rate than whites, according to the newspaper.
Karen Tolvstad, a spokesperson for U.S. Bancorp, denied the charge, saying the bank has "dedicated extra attention to the African-American market."
In 1995, she said, the company declined 12 percent of home-related loan applications from African-Americans, compared to 12.5 percent from white applicants.
She said the Fed "needs to give due consideration" to such complaints but should also consider the many letters of support for the acquisition.

A spokesman for the Fed in Washington said the proposed merger had not yet been placed on the Board of Governors meeting schedule. Normally such mergers are approved without a public hearing, he said.
Banking analysts had mixed views on whether the community protests would delay the closing of the merger.
"It could hold up the deal," said Tom Carley of Jensen Securities in Portland. But he said he had no reason to believe Portland-based U.S. Bancorp had been unfair to minorities.
Steven Schroll of Piper Jaffrey said the commmunity group complaints were "a wasted effort."
"The hostage efforts of the various consumer groups will once again be found to simply waste taxpayers money in an effort to extract a pound of flesh that's not to be extracted," he said.
Schroll said both banks have been scrutizined constantly by regulators as they have expanded. He believes the merger is on a fast track for regulatory approval by July.
